overall_score_comment: Like a therapy session set to a catchy beat — surprisingly self-aware, occasionally profound, but also really wants you to know it's self-aware.
the_roast:
Taylor, honey, we get it — you're the problem! You've told us approximately seventeen times in this song. It's like watching someone apologize for being dramatic by being MORE dramatic. 'I'm the problem, it's me' is the new 'sorry not sorry,' except you really ARE sorry and you want EVERYONE at tea time to validate your self-flagellation. Speaking of which, who has beef at tea time? Are we talking high tea with scones or just Earl Grey with your therapist?

The 'depression works the graveyard shift' line is actually pretty clever — I'll give you that. But then you hit us with 'everybody is a sexy baby'? Ma'am, that phrase requires immediate explanation and possibly a wellness check. Are we talking about attractive infants? Young adults who act childish? A Benjamin Button situation? And comparing yourself to a monster 'slowly lurching toward your favorite city' makes you sound less like a tortured artist and more like Godzilla with anxiety.

The daughter-in-law murder plot twist is WILD. We went from self-deprecating coffee shop poetry to a true crime podcast finale. Nothing says 'I'm introspective' quite like imagining your future daughter-in-law as a gold-digger at your funeral. Also, 'laughing up at us from hell' is a fun admission — at least you know where you're headed! The whole bridge feels like you workshopped it with your lawyer present, just in case someone actually tries to contest the will someday.

cliche_counter.cliche: I'm getting older but not wiser
cliche_counter.quip: Every person at every birthday party after 25 has made this exact observation, usually while drunk

cliche_counter.cliche: Staring at the sun instead of the mirror
cliche_counter.quip: Bold of you to choose literal blindness over metaphorical self-reflection — very on brand though

cliche_counter.cliche: You'll get tired and leave me
cliche_counter.quip: The self-fulfilling prophecy special: predict your own demise enough times and congrats, you manifested it!
The 2020s version of 'I'm not like other girls' is 'I'm worse than other girls, actually'
Nothing screams relatable millennial problems like worrying about inheritance drama — most of us are just hoping to afford retirement

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Sometimes I feel like everybody is a sexy baby
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Creating a phrase that will haunt us all and launching a thousand think pieces
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must explain this concept to every confused parent who overhears it on the radio

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Did you hear my covert narcissism lightly disguised as altruism, like some kind of congressman
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Using 'covert narcissism' in a pop song like it's casual vocabulary
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Required to perform this song at a Psychology 101 conference

lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Making tea time sound like a judgmental HOA meeting
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Banned from all British establishments for slandering their sacred ritual

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I have this dream my daughter-in-law kills me for the money
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Poisoning future family gatherings before they even happen
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must attend family therapy with people who don't even exist yet

hidden_meanings: Clearly, this is a documentary about the ghost of F. Scott Fitzgerald possessing a pop star and forcing her to write a sequel to The Great Gatsby, but from Daisy's perspective and she's on WebMD at 3am. The 'sexy baby' epidemic is obviously a commentary on society's infantilization of women, OR Taylor just watched one too many TikToks and had an existential crisis.
final_verdict: A delightfully self-aware anthem that somehow manages to be both genuinely introspective and hilariously over-the-top. It's what happens when you give someone a therapist, a thesaurus, and a really catchy synth beat — we're all exhausted, but we're still rooting for you, you self-proclaimed anti-hero.
title: Anti-Hero
